item.title: Cybersecurity Learning Resources
item.description: A list of resources that I use to teach myself cybersecurity and recommend. Malware Analysis / Reverse Engineering Online courses Zero2Automated - Advanced Malware Analysis - In progress OpenSecurityTraining2 Reverse Engineering 3201: Symbolic Analysis - July 2023 Reverse Engineering 3011: Reversing C++ Binaries - July 2023 Architecture 1001: x86-64 Assembly - July 2023 Sektor7 RED TEAM Operator: Malware Development Intermediate - May 2023 RED TEAM Operator: Malware Development Essentials - April 2023 TCM Security - Practical Malware Analysis & Triage - February 2023 Books Practical Malware Analysis by Michael Sikorski and Andrew Honig General Online courses Udemy - Chris Greer’s Wireshark Hands-On Course - May 2023 TCM Security Python 201 for Hackers - May 2023 OSINT Fundamentals - March 2023 Practical Windows Forensics - March 2023 HTB Academy - Bug Bounty Hunter role path - January 2023 Books Practical Threat Intelligence and Data-Driven Threat Hunting by Valentina Costa-Gazc√≥n Huntpedia Intelligence-Driven Incident Response by Rebekah Brown, Scott J.

item.title: Reverse Engineering the "Bomb Lab" with Cutter
item.description: Context I recently took the excellent “Architecture 1001: x86-64 Assembly” course offered by Xeno Kovah on OpenSecurityTraining2 to consolidate my knowledge of x86-64 assembly. The final assignment consists in solving the “Bomb Lab”. Although the course suggests to use gdb or WinDbg, I decided to do it differently and use Cutter with the following constraints: Not using debug symbols - this is something Xeno actually recommends if one has some reverse-engineering experience, or want extra challenge Perform a pure static analysis - using gdb/gef would be much smarter here, but I really wanted to practice static analysis Not using rz-ghidra or any decompiler since that would defeat the whole point of the exercise I used Cutter Version 2.

item.title: Forensic Lab setup with REMnux + Sift + FlareVM
item.description: This tutorial will guide you through the setup of a Forensic lab using: VirtualBox 7 REMnux + Sift on Ubuntu 20.04 FlareVM on Windows 10 It is mostly a summary of notes I took while building my own lab. Disclaimer Do not follow this guide blindly! Be very careful during the setup of your forensic lab, especially if you intend to manipulate and/or detonate malware. I am in no way responsible for any harm or damage you may cause and you should always make sure you are operating in a safe environment.

item.title: Vincent Thiery
item.description: TL;DR I am currently working as CISO for Edgelab / Evooq in Switzerland. Also worked as SRE (2y), Software Engineer (3y+), and Quant (2y+). Before that, I studied maths, physics, and quantitative finance. I’m curious, enjoy learning new things, and passionate about cybersecurity. I speak French and English. Feel free to contact me by email. Experiences — Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) @ Edgelab / Evooq Since Sep 2021
